DIV1.P: With the happy Arriuall of that famous and worthy Knight Sr. Thomas Gates: and the well reputed & valiant Captaine Mr. Chri∣stopher Newporte, and others, into England.
¶ With the maner of their distresse in the Iland of Deuils (otherwise called Bermoothawes) where they remayned 42. weekes, & builded two Pynaces, in which they returned into Virginia.
By R. Rich, Gent. one of the Voyage.
LONDON Printed by Edw: Allde, and are to be solde by Iohn Wright at Christ-Church dore. 1610.

DIV1.HEAD: To the Reader.
DIV1.P: how to stile thee I knowe not, per∣haps Learned, perhaps vnlearned: happily cap∣tious, happily enuious: indeed what or how to tearme thee I know not, only as I began I will proceede.

Reader, thou dost peraduenture imagine that I am mercenarie in this busines, and write for money (as your moderne Poets vse) hyred by some of those euer to be admi∣red Aduenturers, to flatter rhe world: No, I disclaime it, I haue knowne the Voyage, past the danger, seene that honorable work of Virginia, & I thanke God am arriud here to tell thee what I haue seene, don, & past: if thou wilt be lieue me so, if not so to: for I can∣not force thee but to thy owne liking: I am a Soldier, blunt and plaine, and so is the
phrase of my newes: and I protest it is true. If thou aske why I put it in Verse? I prethee knowe, it was onely to feede mine owne hu∣mour: I must confesse, that had I not debard my selfe of that large scope which to the wri∣ting of prose is allowed, I should haue much easd my selfe, and giuen thee better content. But I intreat thee to take this as it is; and be∣fore many daies expire, I will promise thee the same worke more at large.

I did feare preuention by some of your writers, if they should haue gotten but some part of the newes by the tayle, and therefore though it be rude, let it passe with thy liking, and in so doing I shall like well of thee: but how euer, I haue not long to stay: if thou wilt be vnnaturall to thy country-man, thou maist, I must not loose my patrymonie; I am for Virginia againe, and so I will bid thee hartily farewell, with an honest verse:

Q.L: As I came hether to see my natiue land,
to waft me backe lend me thy gentle hand.

DIV1.HEAD: Newes from Virginia OF THE HAPPY A¦riuall of that famous & worthy knight Sir Thomas Gates and well reputed and valiant Captaine Newport into England.

LG.L: IT is no idle fabulous tale,
For Truth herselfe is heere arriu'd,
With her, both Gates and Newport come,
Which did deuulge vnto the world,
that they at Sea did dye.
Tis true that Eleauen monthes and more,
And brauely did they glyde the maine,
As if a Courser prowdly backt,
The Seas did rage, the windes did blowe,
Their Ship did leake, her tacklings breake,
But heauen was Pylotte in this storme,
But yet these Worthies forced were,
To runne their Ship betweene two Rockes,
And then on shoare the Iland came,
Some Foule and Tortoyses there were
To kill these swyne, to yeild them food
Their store was spent, and all things scant,
A thousand hogges that dogge did kill,
And with such foode, did in that Ile
The braue Deliuerance one was call'd,
The other Patience had to name,
Two only of their men which there,
And for the losse of those two soules,
A Sonne and Daughter then was borne
The two and forty weekes being past,
Their Ships with hogs well freighted were,
Yet at their home returne they ioyd,
And in the mid'st of discontent,
He heard the greifes on either part,
and sett them free from care.
He comforts them and cheeres their hearts,
He feedes them full and feedes their soules,
The worthy Sir George Somers knight,
Maister Georg Pearcy which is brother,
And landed there: his number was
Ad to the rest and they make full,
Where they vnto their labour fall,
as men that meane to thriue:
Let's pray that heauen may blesse them all
Those men that Vagrants liu'd with vs,
Their Gouernour writes in their praise,
And to th' Aduenturers thus he writes,
For scandall cannot doe vs wrong
God will not let vs fall.
for that our worke is good,
Wee hope to plant a Nation,
To glorifie the Lord tis done,
He that would crosse so good a worke,
to God can be no friend.
There is no feare of hunger here,
for Corne much store here growes,
Much fish the gallant Riuers yeild,
Great store of Fowle, of Venison,
Of Chesnuts, Walnuts, and such like,
There is indeed no want at all:
That wish the worke should not goe on,
with words doe seeme to kill.
And for an instance of their store,
Hath for a present hither sent,
In mannaging so good a worke,
well fraught, and in the same
Some Pearle, some Wainscot and clapbords,
And Iron promist, for tis true,
That he that wants shall haue reliefe,
to such they will be kinde.
And when that they shall thither come,
each man shall haue his share.
A house and garden plot shall haue,
That euery man shall haue a part,
Of generall profit, as if that he
Shall by exchange at his returne,
Paid him in London at first sight,
no man shall cause to grieue:
For 'tis their generall will and wish
Are full eight hundred worthy men,
Good, discreete, their worke is good,
May Heauen assist them in their worke,
and thus our newes is done.
